description:
Stud poker is any of a number of poker variants in which each player receives a mix of face-down and face-up cards dealt in multiple betting rounds. Stud games are also typically non-positional games, meaning that the player who bets first on each round may change from round to round (it is usually the player whose face-up cards make the best hand for the game being played). The cards dealt face down to each individual player are called hole cards, which gave rise to the common English expression ace in the hole for any hidden advantage.

Cards are dealt in a prearranged combination of face-down and face-up rounds, or streets, with a round of betting following each. This is the next-oldest family; as poker progressed from three to five-card hands, they were often dealt one card at a time, either face-down or face-up, with a betting round between each. The most popular stud variant today, seven-card stud, deals two extra cards to each player (three face-down, four face-up) from which they must make the best possible 5-card hand.

Source: Wikipedia, "[en.wikipedia.org]", available under the CC-BY-SA License.

Answer the questions correctly and with a little strategy and luck. Every turn, answer correctly 3 questions on 4 on a specific theme to collect enough money to seize the Champion’s chair. Be careful not to lose everything and challenge the “interim champ” with the Kif-Kif Duals. The player with the Champion’s chair at the end of the game (30 minutes) goes on to play the GRAND JEU DU 21. If the champion answer all the last 21 questions in 150 seconds, he/she is the GRAND CHAMPION.
Only available in french.
Box contains:
396 question cards
40 GRAND JEU DU 21 cards
55 cylinder cards
1 cylinder card container
CHAMPION’S CHAIR card
1 plastic base
1 small box
Game rules
(Description from the publisher)

Lethal spies. Explosions. Deception. A fun, fast-paced strategy card game for 2-4 players. Each turn players draw a card to add to their hand. Your goal is to use these cards to reduce your opponents HP down to 0. With 5 different types of card you can expect each game to be filled with all sorts of combinations.

A small memory game consisting of just nine cards showing fours geckos each. The geckos on each card have different colors, and every color is on exactly six of the cards.
The cards are shown face up so the players can memorize the geckos, then they are turn face-down. 
A color is chosen randomly, and one player asks the other to either turn over four cards showing a gecko of that color, or two colors not showing a gecko of that color.
If the other player manages to do that, they get a point, otherwise not. Then it's the second players turn to randomly choose a color and ask the first player to show or not show geckos in that color.
The game ends after all points are distributed. The player with the most points wins.

Pete the Cat is the coolest cat ever! Based on the best-selling book series, our Pete the Cat games introduce kids to simple learning concepts wrapped up in fun games. Kids develop color recognition, counting and decision-making skills. Keep on movin' and groovin' with Pete the Cat.

In Big Lunch Card Game, kids collect different cards to create a giant groovy sandwich using different colored food cards to win.

Reinforces color recognition and collaborative play
Features characters and images from Pete's Big Lunch

—description from the publisher

Game play:
On a turn, a player will either take the top card from the discard pile (unless it is an action card) or draw the top card from the draw deck and then will discard a card.  If the player discards an action card, then the instructions on that card are followed before the next player takes their turn.

The winner is the first player to build a sandwich by collecting two bread cards and one each of the colored food cards (red, green, yellow, and purple)

Talos: the Arena is an accessible deck-building game that is quickly mastered by everybody, but offers the veteran player great depth of tactics and many paths to victory. In preparation of the final battle in Talos’ arena you will spar with your enemies in search of winning combinations and the greatest heroes to truly represent your individual style and strategy. 
We created the game with the goal of enhancing the experience for everybody while eliminating bad elements common in other games. Thus, the basic mechanisms of the game include the following elements:

• To win you need to constantly interfere in your opponent’s turns, while risking and gaining small and large advantages. You actively play at all times during the game.

• There is no sequence of phases, just a never ending battle of all versus all. Players do not have to wait until the enemy has assembled an unbreakable combination to counteract it. You attack and intercept at will, even if your opponent charges forward.

• The game is designed to make as little restrictions as possible and to maximize the potential of the player’s creativity, cooperation, and clever deceit to affect the outcome.

• There is very little path dependency. There is no sure victor of the game practically until the very last move to ensure that you always have a chance to win and affect the game.

• There is only little preparation for the game. Just shuffle and go.

—description from the designer.

La Planche is an abstract press your luck game for 1 to 4 players.
The board is divided in six zones, numbered from 1 to 6.
Each turn, a player roll a six-sided die and put one of his 6 tokens on the corresponding zone of the board, then he choses to continue rolling or to give the die to the player on his left. If the rolled die shows a number corresponding to a zone that already contains a token, the player who rolled the die takes all the tokens that are on the board, except those on zone 1 (tokens in zone 1 are blocked).
The first player who get rid of all his tokens wins the game.

Five years have passed, and it is the time once again for the Party Congress to assemble. Directives for the continued growth of our great Motherland must be established. Behind the scenes however, there is a power struggle brewing. There are party members who force through new directives solely to advance their own careers. The only certainty is that when the congress ends there will be a new General Secretary and many who stood his or her way will be purged.

In Join the Party, you take on the role of a power-hungry party member. Each turn, you will try to pass a directive with the help of another player. Beware though, there are other bureaucrats who may disagree with your ambitions. That is fine, as such disagreeable party members never survive long. Be careful to not be too disagreeable yourself, or it is you who may end up being purged. The player who has passed the most directives, and in doing so gained the most Victory Points, will be named the new General Secretary of the Party.

—description from the designer

Vertellis - which means "tell us more" in Dutch - is designed to create a moment in which families and friends become much closer by asking in-depth questions. Questions that make you reflect, cherish, and share the important and beautiful moments of life.

Vertellis is played through a total of four rounds.  Cards are stacked in four piles as labeled on the back of each card, Round 1, Round 2, Round 3, and Round 4.  Cards in Round 1 consist of questions answered individually about the past year.  Cards in Round 3 consist of questions answered individually about the upcoming year.

Only in Rounds 2 and 4 can you receive points.  These Rounds consist of three questions each that are answered by everyone.  Each participant can earn a maximum of six points throughout the game. It is possible for more than one player to tie for the win, but we believe that during a successful night everyone's a winner!

It’s a silly sequencing memory game! Kids learn animal sounds as they repeat them in order of the cards: Cow says Moo, Chicken says Bawk. Remembering who said what last and repeating the sequence of sounds is just half the fun! Three wild cards (parrot, fish, and seal) add to the auditory fun as kids are asked to repeat certain sounds, make silly faces, or clap! Make the wrong noise or action and break the sequence (horse says, "Meow"?!), and the other players can grab the soft pig "squeal" on you! Builds brain power and auditory memory. Farm Alarm Game Silly sequencing memory game Encourages memory skills, communication, sequencing, auditory development Repeat the animal sounds in order Three wild cards (parrot, fish, and seal) mean repeat, make funny faces, or clap Make a wrong noise and other players can "squeal" on you! Pig oinks when squeezed! Includes: 42 cards, soft rubber pig, barn storage box 2 or more players

Quiz game about the history of Denmark based on Sigurd Barretts books about the history of Denmark.

The players are famous characters from the Danish history, i.e. H.C Andersen or Margrethe the first. The players have to collect six treasures related to their character. The treasures are randomly spread over the board picturing Denmark.

To collect the treasures the players have answer multiple choise questions about the Danish history. There are three difficulties of questions.

PlingPong is a dexterity game.  The game comes with four (4) interlocking trays to create a single game board, which holds a black cup in the middle and four (4) sets of six (6) colored cups on each tray. Each player get a color (or two (2) colors if playing with two (2) players).

Play is played on any table you can bounce a ping pong ball on. With the board setup diagonally, players shoot over their color, to hit the other player’s cups. In each round players shoot twice, then score the round; empty cups stay on the board, cups with an Odd number of balls come off and cups with an Even number of balls stay on.

The goal is to bounce your shots into the opponent’s cups, while avoiding the black cup in the middle.

If the black cup has an odd numbers of balls, each player who placed a ball in the cup lose one of their cups, and the other players gain a cup. If there is an even number of balls in the black cup, the effect of the black cup is cancelled. Even if you have no cups left, you are still in the game, because you will get one back when someone makes a black cup shot.

The last player with cups on the board wins.

The game of quick thinking and fast talking!
It should be easy to name 3 animals found in a zoo - but can you do it under the pressure of 5 seconds twisting down and with the other players staring, waiting for you to get flustered? Time is not on your side, so just say what comes to mind and risk ridiculous answers slipping out as time twirls down on the spiral timer.
There are opportunities to 'duck' the questions or inflict 'pain' on your opponents by use of the SWITCH or PASS ON cards.
Contents:
90 Question cards (180 questions)
6 PASS ON cards
6 SWITCH cards
1 Spiral timer
1 Set of rules

Strange and terrible things have begun happening in Hawkins, Indiana… better huddle down and break out a nice board game with your pals!

     Monopoly game with a Stranger Things theme
     Features 80s-inspired tokens and tokens “ripped from the Upside Down”
     Walkie-Talkie and Blinking Lights cards as Community Chest and Chance cards

In When Cutie Met Patootie, we meet Cutie, the residents of Kodiak Harbor, and the ten alien visitors who have just arrived on nearby Alaskan shores. Cutie has been in the care of her grandmother while her archeologist parents are on a dangerous expedition. However, after their being gone for six months, Cutie and the residents of Kodiak Harbor fear the worst. Join Cutie as she travels into the forest with Amelia, one of the visitors, to discover the truth of her parents' whereabouts.

At the beginning of the game, players take a secret Citizen card and three path cards, then they randomly assemble the Alaskan shore visitor cards in a row of ten and place the corresponding Visitor pieces on their card.

Players then take turns playing a path card each turn. Path cards can be used in multiple ways: build the growing map, help visitors collect sprite gems, or spend those sprite gems to advance visitors along the built map. When building the map, players can connect only to the existing path to create a pyramid shape, ever tightening the forest path!

The end of the game is triggered when one visitor reaches the top. To determine a winner, players reveal their secret roles, each detailing specific sprite gems for which they earn points. Players tally points based on the location of visitors holding their designated sprite gems. The person with the most sprite gem points wins!

When Cutie Met Patootie is the first game of The Entanglement Series by The Daniel Zayas Company. This game ships with a mini-expansion titled The Man Who Moves the Water, which allows for solo play.

Fourth Quarter Football miniatures game, recreating the thrill of gridiron football.

Coaches select plays from a play deck they have designed, in an attempt to outwit their opponents. The plays selected are played out on the highly detailed game field, with fantastically detailed miniatures. Players are rewarded for sticking to the planned plays, but it's the fourth quarter, and things get tough, and crucially, players make mistakes.

The game uses a unique two phase movement mechanism to recreate the feel of a football game, but plays in under one and a half hours.
Any actions are decided by dice rolls, but the chances of success depend on the skills and the placement of the players involved.

—description from the publisher

On September 18th 1941 the Italian submarine Sciré released 3 two-man crew S.L.C (Siluro a Lenta Corsa) Maiale (Pig) class mini-submarines to attack Allied shipping in what many thought was an impregnable harbor, safe from any enemy attack. The Italian raiders sank three merchant vessels; the cargo ship Durham and two tankers, Denbydale and Fiona. For their daring raid, all 6 of the Italian frogmen, as well as the entire crew of the submarine Sciré were hailed as heroes.

The active player takes on the role of the commanders of the three or four, Maiale class mini-submarines. You must endeavor to overcome the Allied defenses and night-time visibility to inflict as much damage as possible before being killed, captured or escaping, and then return to the Sciré. Can you do as well or better?

Each copy of Depths of Courage: The Raid on Gibraltar is composed of the following:


     One 11 by 17 inch point-to-point map.
     22 double-sided, un-mounted counters
     2 pages of rules


A player will also need a standard deck of playing cards and a six-sided die to play the game.

—description from the publisher

The Valor & Steel & Flesh battle rules allow you to blend the amazing steam and Victorian scientific romance with the soldiers and weapons of historical colonial era warfare and - with a dash of heroics and whimsy - get that curiously delightful blend known as Victorian Science Fiction gaming.

Valor & Steel & Flesh features the wonders of steam technology (colossi, landships, elctro-cannon, Etc.) and the awesome might of otherworldly marvels (flying ships, heat rays, alien creatures, etc.).

While based on the renowned Brother Against Brother system (originally designed by Ivor Janci) from H.G. Walls, Valor & Steel & Flesh does not use a strict historical, or even alternately historical, approach, leaning rather heavily towards the heroic approach so favored by Hollywood in its “historical” productions.

A pocket dice version of poker this game consists of 5 six-sided dice. There are 4 Aces, 4 Kings, 4 Queens, 4 Jacks, 4 10s, 4 9s, 2 Jokers and an extra set of hearts in Ace, King, Queen, and Jack. Total "cards" is 30.

In Roll Poker any number can play. To start, each person puts 10 chips in the kitty. The starting player and everyone following contributes one chip to the kitty. Payoff on each scoring roll is as follows:
                Pay Off
Any two pairs - Free Throw
2 Aces and any pair - 2-1
Any 3 of a kind 2-1
3 Aces          6-1
Straight        8-1
Any full house  10-1
Any 4 of a kind 12-1
4 Aces          20-1
Any 5 of a kind 20-1
5 Aces          30-1
Royal Flush     40-1

Any chips remaining at end of game are distributed evenly.

There are also 3 other variations called Royal Flush, Sudden Death, and Total Poker

Craits (sometimes spelled Crates or Creights) is a card game played by anywhere between two and five players. It was invented in the 1970s in Cambridge, Massachusetts, and is derived from Crazy Eights; in fact, the name Craits is derived from Crazy Eights itself. Craits is similar to the marketed game Uno, which has its own specialized deck, and many cards assume the functions of Uno's specialized cards.

The goal of the game is to be the first to get rid of all your cards. When it is your turn, you may play a card from your hand that matches either the suit or the rank of the most recent card played. If you cannot (or choose not to ) play, you draw instead.

Many cards have additional effects, such as forcing other players to draw, reversing the direction of play, etc.

Its like dominoes but with maps, as you build a map of the United States, by connecting states that share a common border. Stay one step ahead of your opponents, as you race to be the first player to play all your county cards on the table and win the game.

Take a boat through the Pacific Ocean to Alaska or Hawaii, or block Maine be controlling New Hampshire

In ç›¸å ´æ“ç¸¦ (Market Manipulation), each player secretly represents a company, with as many companies in the game as the number of players. Each company in the game has a deck of eight tiles, with point values on the back of these tiles.

The start player in a round draws one tile from each company, looks at the point values for each of them, discards one from play, then places the others in a column with some of them above the break-even line (a thick string) and others below. Each other player in turn either moves one tile from the top of the column to the bottom (or vice versa) while keeping the column in the same position relative to the break-even line or moves the column up or down by one level. The starting player for the round does this action last, then this position rotates clockwise, and the next starting player begins another round.

After eight rounds, the game ends and the point values of all tiles above the break-even line are revealed. The player who owns the company with the highest collective value wins!

In Animale Tattica, players race to empty their hand first.

Each player has a different deck of sixteen cards. Usually you have to play cards with a higher rank than those played by the previous player, but if you've collected cards of the same rank and the total of that rank equals the total of the rank that previous player played, you can play those cards instead.

If you can master the poker face, And read the faces of others. If you've got the calm for Russian roulette, But can make others fall under pressure. If you can charm, and not be charmed yourself. And manipulate but not be manipulated. If you can persuade like a King, But not be led astray. And make others believe in illusions, By creating smoke and mirrors. If you can adapt when the odds are against you, And look cool when the game turns. If you can win in the face of defeat. And know when to lose a won game. Then my friend.... You have what it takes to be a Great Hustler. Hustle card game is an exciting new game that'll have you and your friends and family hooked. It's a fast-paced game that changes at every turn. One minute you're winning, and then suddenly the odds are against you. The next minute you may be losing but using your charm and skill and with a little bit of luck you can win in the face of defeat. The rules are simple and very quick to master. It's a game that requires confidence, skill and keeping cool under pressure. Call out values for opponents to match and the first to get rid of all cards wins the game. But be careful of different Hustle cards and opponents who may try to charm, manipulate and hustle to a win. Perfect for all ages and for bringing friends and family together. Remember you can either Hustle or be Hustled!!

—description from the back of the box

THE PURPOSE OF THE GAME: To be the player who has converted the most "Oxygen" throughout his course.
THE RULE OF THE GAME: Who will have enough oxygen to finish the game? "Depending on your behavior on the course, you will quickly see that your Oxygen supply is limited. You will be able to stay on some huts to try to make more ecological gestures that will give you Oxygen. You will be able to plant trees to put Oxygen in the wind farm or to walk there to take a breath of Oxygen. Be environmentally friendly, the first come will not necessarily be the winner.
Everyone will discover that they can choose to adopt behaviors in favor of a less polluting means of transport.

This game claims to be the funniest game in the world. Two players try to move 4 pawns from the base of the board beyond the dark spot between the snake heads. pawns that actually get on the dark spot have to begin anew. Movement is determined b a die. If the roll of the die shows a result that allows a pawn to get on the dark spot, it has to be used for this pawn. The small black dots (crossroads) can be occupied by any number of pawns of the same color. If a pawn gets on a crossroad, that is occupid by one or more pawns of the other color, the other pawns have to go back to the next crossroads behind them. If a pawn has the opportunity to reach a crossroads, it has to do that. The first player to get all 4 pawns off the game board beyond the dark spot wins the game.

The kingdom's most celebrated warriors have come from far and wide to do combat in a grand tournament that will determine who is the fiercest of them all. Each has a personal reason for competing in the event, but there is a single thread that unites all of them: the desire to put their fighting skills on display in order to earn the right to be called champion.

Sainome Colosseum R is an ultra-accessible and fast-paced PvP combat game for 2-4 players that allows players to take on chosen character roles, each with an assortment of individual skills and abilities, to do battle with one another in an epic gladiatorial showdown. Using action selection, hand management, card drafting, and dice rolling, Sainome Colosseum R gives players important decision points while blending strategy, luck, and balanced replayability. As you explore the game, you discover the strengths and weaknesses of each fighter as well as interesting combinations that can put your opponents down for the count.

On each turn, a player chooses two out of five actions, resolves both, then discards to meet the hand limit requirements. To gain the advantage in battle, gear can be attached to your character by physically placing equipment cards on any side of your fighter with a corresponding slot. These equipment cards can then activated using a unique dice mechanism to attack your opponents and initiate a wide range of special effects. Adding further to this dynamic gameplay is the ability for each character to transform from their beginning Normal Form to a heightened Awakened Form, which grants skill upgrades. The player who best utilizes these various systems to reduce their opponent's HP to 0 is ultimately the winner!

Kwis ‘t! is a quizgame with a twist. You are able to win without answering most questions correct. You win Kwis ‘t! by psychology, knowing your facts and a little luck. Every player answers the same five questions per round. After the correct answers have been given to you, you put your marker on how many questions you’ve answered correct. However, you can bluff! You can earn bonus by fooling your opponents and by calling a bluff of an opponent. Use your reputation as a walking encyclopaedia or a notorious braggart. If you outsmart your opponents, you win Kwis ‘t!

Kwis ‘t! is Dutch for Quiz it. If you pronounce it fast, it sounds like ‘I knew it’ (In Dutch). The game has easy game rules and contains lots of verbal and non-verbal interaction.

Kwis ‘t! has more than 1.150 original questions in all different kinds of categories. Every set of five questions consists of two open questions, two multiple choice questions (with A, B and C) and one 50/50 question. If you don’t know the answer, you can still make an educated guess. You guessed wrong? You can still bluff that you gave the correct answer.

Who thinks they can reach their nose with their tongue? And who can puff out their cheeks the most? The monster-sized funny faces provide guaranteed fun. Here we go! Throw dice, find a monster, make a monster face. A silly game for 2-4 players ages 5-99 that playfully helps to encourage verbal and motor skills.

—description from the publisher

Chibi Commander is a strategy game for 1 to 4 players. You command a squad of specialists. Try to fight against the Aliens or take over the command of this dark minded Enemies yourself. Play together with your friends in coop or against them. Or even play it alone against the game itself.

Play missions in many different locations, single or in campaign mode. Rescue civilians, try to steal technology, defend or attack targets, kidnap enemies and much more. Place trees, covers, craters, streets, giant mosters and hole UFOs which landed on the map.

Control 4 totally different races with a total of 80 units including civilians and animals. After each mission you will gain victory points which will allow you to upgrade your soldiers in secret.

The rules are very optimized and allows playing whole campaigns during one evening.

—description from the publisher

Board game for the whole family.

Do you have what it takes to build a new state and culminate the history of Catalonia?

Rate and win your freedom!

Goal of the game:
The objective of the game is to collect the six cards"Som i Serem"and deposit them in the ballot box.

Game preparation:
Each player chooses a donkey and puts it in the starting box. The cards "Som i Serem" are mixed well, the cards ask and the letters of Saint George and the Dragon, and they are placed face down in their respective spaces on the board. Each player prepares an urn and puts it in front of him. Before beginning, each player takes 3 cards We and We will be from the stack. The game starts with the youngest player.

The boxes:
Each time we go through the start box we collect a "Som i Serem" card.
Make holidays in the Pyrenees, the Costa Brava and the Ebro Delta.
Go back to the Festa Major and the Sant Jordi Day.
Dialogue to Parliament.
Take unilateral action for the Good Sickle.
And if you put an urn in front of you, you know ... vote!

How to win:
Win the first person who introduces the six cards "Som i Serem" in the ballot box and reach the nearest Parliament box.
Once in the Parliament box, a parliamentary majority must be obtained by throwing the dice and removing 4 or more.
Once achieved, the game is won.
Live in Catalonia!

—description from the designer (translated)

Joc de taula per a tota la família.

Tens el que cal per construir un nou estat i culminar la història de Catalunya?

Vota i guanya la teva llibertat!

Contingut: 
4 rucs 
1 dau 
1 tauler de joc (40x40) 
60 cartes Som i Serem 
60 cartes de preguntes 
30 cartes de Sant Jordi i el Drac

Objectiu del joc:
L’objectiu del joc és recollir les sis cartes Som i Serem i dipositar-les a l’urna.

Preparació del joc:
Cada jugador tria un ruc i el posa a la casella d’inici. Es barregen bé les cartes Som i Serem, les cartes pregunta i les cartes de Sant Jordi i el Drac, i es col·loquen cap per avall en els seus respectius espais al tauler. Cada jugador es prepara una urna i la posa davant seu. Abans de començar, cada jugador agafa 3 cartes Som i Serem de la pila. La partida comença amb el jugador més jove.

Les caselles:
Cada cop que es passi per la casella d’inici es recull una carta Som i Serem.
Fes vacances als Pirineus, la Costa Brava i el Delta del Ebre.
Torna a tirar a la Festa Major i a la Diada de Sant Jordi.
Dialoga al Parlament.
Pren acció unilateral al Bon Cop de Falç.
I si et posen una urna davant, ja saps … vota!

Com es guanya:
Guanya la primera persona que introdueix les sis cartes Som i Serem dins l’urna i arriba a la casella de Parlament més propera.
Un cop a la casella de Parlament, s’ha d’assolir majoria parlamentària tirant el dau i treient un 4 o més.
Un cop aconseguit, es guanya el joc.
Visca Catalunya!
—description from the designer

ãƒ•ã‚¿ãƒªã‚·ãƒ­ (Futarishiro) is a castle-building game set in the age of warring states. To win, you must build a castle that's harder to overcome that the opponent's. Perhaps you can build a moat, arrange a tower, store weapons, train soldiers, and prepare for battle.

It's difficult to build a castle exactly as desired, though, as you have to read the psychology of your opponent to get the castle tiles that you want and design your territory in the best way.

Step into the streets and alleyways of the ancient Roman Empire. Those streets have become rife with carnage and unrest in these uncertain times. Gangs of brutal Fighters are used as weapons to exert the will of their paymasters. These paymasters, known as Domini, are ambitious heads of Roman households; as such a Dominus you begin your story in troubled times...

Gangs of Rome is a new skirmish game from War Banner in which you will use unique fighters, pitting them against the gangs of rival Domini in both campaign and scenario play to earn influence enough to manipulate your way into the Senate. Then, as a Senator of Rome, you will be granted the power destroy your enemies with methods far greater than the sword.

So hold on to your sandals and watch your back, Dominus!

Things are about to get bloody…

—description from the designer

Fake News / Real News is the fast-paced card game where players have to decide what's Fake News and what's Real News. Whether you politically lean left, lean right, or drive right down the middle, everyone can join in the fun. If you can decipher the real statements from the fake ones and determine which member of the administration said it then you will be the winner of Fake news / Real News, and have bragging rights through the next media cycle!

In Noboribetsu, a.k.a. ã®ã¼ã‚Šã¹ã¤, each player wants to build a fine city, but you never know what you're going to get — and in the end your plans might just get shot to hell anyway.

Each player starts with an onsen (hot springs) card, and a deck of twelve locations, twelve characters, and four Hell cards is shuffled. On a turn, the active player rolls the die. On a roll of 2-5, they take the top card of the deck and add it to their city. If it's a location, they place it on the road from their hot springs; if it's a character they place it in a location or hot springs; if it's Hell, hey, it's also a location, so it gets connected to the road.

On a roll of 1 or 6, the first player to call "Noboribetsu!" gets to take the taxi (which allows them to draw two cards on a roll of 2-5) and move one top card in a city. They can steal an opponent's location or character; they can move a character to a matching location; or they can place a lone Hell card on an opponent's location.

When the deck runs out, players score nothing for Hell-inflicted locations, 2 points for each location and matching character card on it, and 1 point for all other cards. Whoever scores the most points earns 1 victory point, and after multiple games whoever earns 3 victory points first wins.

A wildly uproarious storytelling game that’s sure to be
a hit at any party. You and your friends will spin tales that
take such bizarre and unexpected turns that you’ll be
rolling on the floor with laughter!

Will you be the first to complete your game card and make it backstage?  One Direction: The Game is a themed game for 2-4 players in which you answer questions, take challenges or complete actions in order to collect tokens.  Each token represents an item of One Direction memorabilia.  The object of the game is to be the first player to fill your game card with autographs, collectables and concert items.  Only the winner receives the backstage VIP pass necessary to complete their game card.

Players take it in turns to pick up cards that bring them closer to collecting tokens.  Do You Know? cards require the player to answer a question about One Direction to receive a token.  Action Cards for example may cause the player to miss a turn or trade tokens with another player.  Will You Dare? cards are family-friendly challenges such as "Do the chicken dance for 20 seconds" or "Sing happy birthday in a way that would get Harry's attention".

DinoBattle is a card game for 2-5 players, consisting of 45 dino cards, 6 survival cards, and 6 event cards. The dino cards show an image of a dinosaur or a meteorite. At the top of the cards there are one or more small icons of dino’s that can be defeated by that dino card. In DinoBattle every player receives four dino cards, and the player whose turn it is has to act on the last played dinosaur.

The smallest scavengers are eaten by the medium sized hunters. Medium sized hunters are in turn eaten by the bigger dinos that also eat each other or can be defeated by smaller dinos working together well. Even the biggest dinos are not safe, because the meteorite can be fatal for them and thus mark a new beginning for the scavengers.
After playing a card, the player replenishes his hand, unless the player failed to play a card that fitted the previous dino card. In that case the player plays on with a hand with one card less. The game ends when a player cannot play his last card, and the player with the most cards in hand wins the game. In case of a draw, the winners play a knock out round until one winner is left.
It is also possible to play multiple rounds. In that case, each remaining hand card counts as 1 point, and the game ends when a player has 10 points or more.

The basic game of DinoBattle is already very playable for children from 8 years, but the game contains optional cards that can make the game more challenging and interesting for older players
and veterans.
The survival cards offer each player a second chance and give players the possibility to survive for longer in though situations. There are three different survival cards, each with two different options that can offer salvation.
Event cards add new tactical elements and offer players the possibility to achieve a unique advantage over the other players. These cards are face up on the table, visible for all players. Each player can use one event card during his turn. Used event cards are no longer available for other players. Which event card can be played depends on the dino card that is on top of the discard pile.
When these optional cards are used, it is no longer possible to play another card than the askes card.

If you cannot play a matching card, you are out of the game for this round. The last remaining player wins the round, and the player who wins the most rounds, wins the game.

—description from the publisher

Ride a rocket to extraordinary destinations across our galaxy. During your travels you will gather exotic crystals that further our understanding of what’s out there. Use these crystals to complete exploration badges and turn them in at the mysterious Outpost 13 to prove yourself as the galaxy’s next great space explorer!

Space Park features a modular board where seven destinations are randomly arranged to form a circle between players. During a player's turn, rockets will be on three of the board's seven destinations. These rockets symbolize what destinations are available for a player to travel to. Once a player travels to a destination by performing its action, that rocket moves to the next open destination clockwise.

Destinations feature actions such as gaining a certain type of crystal, acquiring a new badge to work toward, turning in your crystals for Explorer Points, or using your trusty explorer-bot Scout to help out. The player with the most Explorer Points at the end of the game wins.

—description from the publisher

The idea behind Pytagora is to have, instead of puzzle pieces with words, "arithmetic pieces": the ten digits from 0 to 9 and the four signs of addition, subtraction, multiplication and division, in addition to the sign of equality. The pieces are used to compose equalities and the game rewards you with more points for better combinations (numbers with more digits, using division or multiplication, using a piece already on the table).

A space skill game from the American Toy Works, Brooklyn. The game requires players to use suction cup darts to knock down two rockets that are balanced on a vertical stand that is decorated with a Bulls eye and space scenes.

Each player has two shots to score points either by hitting the Bulls eye target or knocking the rockets off the stand. Highest score wins.
A variation of the game requires players to knock down the left rocket first and hit specific space scenes on the stand before finally knocking the right rocket down to win. Players load the suction cup dart into a shooter that resembles a small wooden bat with a central hole. The shooter has a rubber band stretched over the dart end to fire the dart at the targets.

American Games (A. Malloy) lists the game as being published in 1939.

Memorise and find the hidden fruits and vegetables corresponding to spring, summer, autumn and winter. Be the smartest to complete your season first, but watch out for the wind and the lumberjack !

A game which allows children to practice their memory and observation skills.

A game of political satire. A parody of 2016 Lithuanian Parliament election.

You are the leader of a political party which has 10 members. There are only two months left until the elections and events occur every day leaving no time for rest. On your road to success you will deal with social, economic and internal events and of course you will be part of scandals. By successfully resolving an event you will obtain rating points however by being part of a scandal you will lose them. You will be able to exchange rating points to the control of ministries and that will determine who will rule Šeimas.

In Šeimas as well as in Seimas (Lithuanian Parlament) the elections is the time for challenges.

—description from the back of the box (translated)

Each player has 10 party member cards. Each party member has positive or negative competence points in each of the four fields (economic, internal affairs, social and scandals). The five event cards are picked, which represent an event happening each day of the working week. Events might be positive (economic, internal affairs or social) or negative (scandal). One event is opened and players bid party member to win (resolve) the event or not to be part of a scandal. Winning the event gains you rating points, which can be combined to obtain the control of ministries. By participating in a scandal players lose rating points, which can lead to losing the control of ministries. After the week ends (fifth event is resolved), played party members are returned to the player and the new week is started. The game is finished after two in-game months (8 weeks or 40 events) or when one player controls at least 7 (out of 14) ministries. The winner is the player who controls ministries which required most rating points to obtain.

—user summary

In Dealt!, first released as Krass Kariert (Checkered Combos) then later as Combo Up, you don't necessarily win by going out first, but at least you don't lose the game.

To start, each player receives three life tokens and two reserve cards at random, which they place face up in front of themselves. They then receive a hand of cards, the order of which they cannot change. The start player for a round leads by playing a combination of up to three cards, and these cards must be next to one another in that player's hand. A player can lay down a single card, a pair, a triple, or a run of two or three consecutive cards. Each player in turn must beat the combination, with a pair being beaten by a higher pair or a triple. If you cannot or will not play, you instead pick up one of your reserve cards, placing it where you choose within your hand. If you have no more reserve cards, then you must discard a life token.

Once each player has played or passed, whoever played the highest combination wins that round and begins the next round. If a player must discard a life token but has none, this player loses the game and everyone else wins.

Combo Up includes four new special action cards, but is otherwise identical in gameplay to the original release.

Overview and Theme: In Resilience, you will lead your armies to capture lands for your chosen banner, trade resources with your neighbors, negotiate terms with your allies and your enemies, build mighty strongholds and battle those who stand in your way! You will choose the actions for each of your armies that will in turn, change the shape of the land and the outcome of the game.

Goal: The game of Resilience is played with 2 to 4 players, each attempting to be the first to build a level 4 stronghold and become the winner of the game. The levels of a stronghold are as follows: 1-Keep 2-Wall 3-Moat 4-Victory

The Game Board: The game is played on square land tiles that are laid down between the player's war camps. The land tiles are one of three types, Desert, Plains or Forest, each having a different land value associated with them. The more land value a player controls, the higher they can build their stronghold to win the game.

Some of the land tiles have mountains that limit where a player's commander can move to and may be rotated by the players to alter the game board, benefiting or hindering a player's strategy.

Game-Play: Each player has 3 commanders that they use to move around the game board and interact with the land tiles. On each player's turn, they may use each commander once to claim land tiles, use special abilities or battle opponent commanders.

Battle: Each commander has an army that is made up of 1 to 3 army cards. Army cards may be; Infantry, Archer, Cavalry or a Diplomat. In a Rock-Paper-Scissor fashion each player reveals cards, one at a time, from the commander army to battle: Infantry beats Cavalry, Cavalry beats Archer, Archer beats Infantry. The diplomat serves as the wild-card; when used in battle, both players are forced to roll a 6-sided die to determine the victor of that particular fight.

Trading: Players may trade away land tiles they control to other willing players, and in return, they re-collect army cards that have been discarded or resurrect fallen commanders.

Fun fact: No player can truly be eliminated. Even if a player looses all of their commanders and land tiles, they can always accept trade from other players, bringing them back into the game.

Pirates Chase Game is a simple spin-and-move game for 2 players. One player plays the part of the Pirates (who controls 3 ships) and the other player is the Cargo Ship Captain (who controls 1 ship). The object of the game is for the Pirate player to land exactly on the same space as the Cargo Ship with on of his ships, thus winning the game for the pirates. If the Cargo Ship is able to make it once around the board without being sunk, then the Cargo Ship Captain player wins the game.

—user summary

Land Ahead! is a fast-paced game in which players together explore an unexplored island. The players take turns placing six-sided island tiles, forming the coast lines, locations and roads of the island.

The game is highly strategic as tiles will have to be placed in ways that benefit you, forming roads for your player figure to follow. This while preventing other players from reaching the island’s locations before you!

Every time a location is discovered, a round event token is placed on top of the location. These tokens depict villages, castles and forests and trigger events when reached by one of the players.

Will you befriend a stray animal that can help you on your journey or will you be attacked by a fearsome monster? Perhaps find powerful equipment or valuable treasure?

During the game you will improve your abilities by finding equipment and placing it on the corresponding equipment slot of your player tile. All equipment will improve either your offense, defense or movement ability to some extent.

Will you become powerful enough to defeat the monsters and win the game as the monster slayer? Maybe you’ll become great at evading attacks while collecting treasure and win the game as the treasure hunter?

One thing is for sure - no two games will ever be the same!

—description from the designer

Boardgame adapted from the very popular French comic "Les Légendaires".

Run a extraordinary adventure with magic and fantasy.
Being one of their favorite character (Danaël, Jadina, Gryf, Shimy or Razzia), the players will have to cooperate in order to solve the challenges given by the Guardian and save Alysia's World.
—description from the publisher (translated)

Vivez une extraordinaire aventure grâce à ce jeu de plateau mêlant la magie et le fantastique ! En incarnant Danaël, Jadina, Gryf, Shimy ou Razzia, chaque joueur doit collaborer avec les autres pour résoudre les défis lancés par le Gardien et sauver le monde d'Alysia.
—description from the publisher (French)
A trivia box of over 700 questions and 130 challenges about TV Series, Litterature, Movies, Comics, Mangas and Anime, and Video Games.
